title: Mijiu
text:
Mijiu () is a Chinese <a href="rice%20wine">rice wine</a> made from <a href="glutinous%20rice">glutinous rice</a>. It is generally clear in appearance with balanced sweetness and acidity, similar to its Japanese counterpart <a href="sake">sake</a> and Korean counterpart <a href="Cheongju%20%28beverage%29">cheongju</a>. The alcohol content ranges between 15% and 20%. Rice wine was made around or before 1000 BC in ancient China, and then the practice spread to Japan and other <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a>n countries. Since then, it has played an important role in Chinese life. In most Chinese supermarkets there are various kinds of rice wines. It is a traditional beverage to the Chinese and some of the families still follow the custom of making rice wine by themselves. The rice wine is made using glutinous rice, Chinese yeast and water. It is also served as an <a href="aperitif">aperitif</a> and is believed to be beneficial in improving metabolism and skin.
Mijiu is usually drunk warm, like the Japanese sake and Korean cheongju, and is also used in <a href="Chinese%20cuisine">cooking</a>. The cooking mijiu available in <a href="Asian%20supermarket">Asian grocery stores</a> are generally of a lower quality, and often contain added <a href="Edible%20salt">salt</a> to avoid an alcohol tax. Mijiu is produced in <a href="China">mainland China</a> and <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.
A type of <a href="baijiu">baijiu</a> called <a href="rice%20baijiu">rice baijiu</a> () is distilled from mijiu.
An unfiltered form of Chinese rice wine containing whole glutinous rice grains of extremely low alcoholic content and often consumed by children is called <a href="jiuniang">jiǔniàng</a> () or láozāo ().
In Taiwan, the <a href="Taiwan%20Tobacco%20and%20Liquor%20Corporation">Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corporation</a> (Monopoly Bureau) is the main manufacturer, branded as Taiwan red label. The <a href="alcohol%20content">alcohol content</a> is 19.5%.
Mijiu is commonly used in cooking dishes such as ginger <a href="duck">duck</a>, <a href="sesame%20oil">sesame oil</a> <a href="chicken">chicken</a>, and shochu chicken.
Usage.
The traditional way to use mijiu is to boil three bottles and evaporate the alcohol while cooking with the chicken. It is believed that by using this recipe one can help women's rehabilitation wound. Mijiu is also used in Jiuniang which is a dish that consists of the rice wine, rice particles, and sometimes glutinous rice balls.
